review.title: Medical Concept Representation Learning from Electronic Health Records and its Application on Heart Failure Prediction
review.abstract: Objective: To transform heterogeneous clinical data from electronic health records into clinically meaningful constructed features using data driven method that rely, in part, on temporal relations among data. Materials and Methods: The clinically meaningful representations of medical concepts and patients are the key for health analytic applications. Most of existing approaches directly construct features mapped to raw data (e.g., ICD or CPT codes), or utilize some ontology mapping such as SNOMED codes. However, none of the existing approaches leverage EHR data directly for learning such concept representation. We propose a new way to represent heterogeneous medical concepts (e.g., diagnoses, medications and procedures) based on co-occurrence patterns in longitudinal electronic health records. The intuition behind the method is to map medical concepts that are co-occuring closely in time to similar concept vectors so that their distance will be small. We also derive a simple method to construct patient vectors from the related medical concept vectors. Results: We evaluate similar medical concepts across diagnosis, medication and procedure. The results show xx% relevancy between similar pairs of medical concepts. Our proposed representation significantly improves the predictive modeling performance for onset of heart failure (HF), where classification methods (e.g. logistic regression, neural network, support vector machine and K-nearest neighbors) achieve up to 23% improvement in area under the ROC curve (AUC) using this proposed representation. Conclusion: We proposed an effective method for patient and medical concept representation learning. The resulting representation can map relevant concepts together and also improves predictive modeling performance.

sections.heading: MATERIALS AND METHODS
sections.text: In Figure 1, we provide a high-level overview of the steps we take to perform the HFD prediction. In the training phase, we first train medical concept vectors from the EHRdataset using Skip-gram. We then construct patient representation using the medical concept vectors. Patient representation is then used to train heart failure prediction models using various classifiers, namely logistic regression, support vector machine (SVM), multi-layer perceptron with a hidden layer (MLP), and K-nearest neighbors. In the prediction phase, we map a patient's medical records using tomedical concept vectors and generate patient vectors by aggregating the concept vectors. We then insert the patient vectors into the trained model, which in turn generates a score for heart failure.

sections.heading: EXPERIMENTS AND RESULTS
sections.text: Population and data source came from the Sutter Palo Alto Medical Foundation (Sutter-PAMF), a large primary care and multi-specialized group practice that has been using an EHR for more than a decade. Study dataset was extracted from cases and controls identified during the period from May 16, 2000 to May 23, 2013. EHR data included demographic data, smoking and alcohol consumption, clinical and laboratory data, International Classification of Disease Version 9 (ICD-9) codes associated with encounters, dispositions and referrals, procedural information in current procedural terminology (CPT), and drug prescription information in medical terms. The dataset included 265,336 patients with a total of 555,609 unique clinical events.

sections.heading: Configuration for Medical Concept Representation Learning
sections.text: To apply Skip-gram, we scanned all 265,336 patients in chronological order and extracted diagnostic, drug, and procedure codes assigned to each patient. If a patient received multiple diagnoses, drugs, or procedures during a single visit, we received the same timestamp. The respective number of unique diagnoses, drugs, and procedures was 11,460, 17,769, and 9,370, totaling 38,599 unique medical concepts. We used 100-dimensional vectors to represent medical concepts (i.e. D = 100 in Figure 2 (b)), with 300 being sufficient to effectively represent 692,000 vocabularies in the NLP. sections.heading: Future Work
sections.text: Although medical concept vectors have shown impressive results, it would be even more effective if deeper medical information such as laboratory results or patient demographic information could be embedded, which would enable us to better represent the medical condition of patients. Drawing on expertise is another thing we should try. Although we have shown impressive performance only from medical records, this does not mean that we cannot benefit from established medical expertise, such as specific characteristics or medical ontologies. Another natural extension of our work is to solve other medical problems. Although this work has focused on early detection of heart failure, our approach is fairly general that it could be applied to any kind of disease prediction problem, and thematic concept vectors can also be used in many medical applications.

sections.heading: CONCLUSION
sections.text: We qualitatively demonstrated that the trained medical concept vectors actually captured medical insights that are compatible with our medical knowledge and experience. In terms of the task of predicting heart failure, medical concept vectors improved the performance of many classifiers, demonstrating their effectiveness quantitatively. We discussed the limitations of our method and possible future work, including the deperutilization of medical information, the combination of expertise within our framework, and the expansion of our approach to various medical applications.
